fields.description: The Mid-Atlantic is home to important naval installations and training areas, and it’s a busy corridor for commercial shipping and naval and other defense and security operations.
fields.overview:
The Mid-Atlantic region is a busy corridor for commercial and recreational ship traffic and is home to the world’s largest naval base, as well as many other military installations and training grounds. The U.S. Coast Guard works with other agencies to ensure that navigation routes for both commercial and defense vessels are accessible and safe. Their security focus is on the safety of ports, vessels, and facilities, both on and away from shore and their presence is notable throughout the region, with bases in Norfolk, Baltimore, Cape May, and Staten Island.

The Naval Station at Norfolk, Virginia supports 75 large ships and 130 aircraft on seven miles of piers and wharfs, and it houses the largest concentration of Navy personnel in the country. Every year, its Port Services branch oversees more than 3,000 maneuvers as ships arrive and depart their berths. Spatial planners and resource managers must account for this intensive activity and work with military leaders to ensure their missions are not compromised as planning decisions are made.

The legal framework supporting maritime security in the U.S. is based on five principal laws:

  • Espionage Act (1917) – enabled the Coast Guard to make regulations to prevent losses to harbors and vessels during national emergencies.
  • Magnusson Act (1950) – provided permanent port security regulations and allowance to control movement of foreign vessels in U.S. ports.
  • Ports and Waterways Safety Act (1972) – allowed additional protection for port facilities and improved efforts to avoid degrading the marine environment.
  • Maritime Transportation Security Act (2002) – provided broad authority to prevent acts of terrorism within U.S. waters.
  • International Ship and Port Facility Security Code (2002) – amendments to International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea to enhance maritime security.

Data under development for the Security theme will include areas with potential hazards or public use restrictions and other information deemed to be critical for spatial planning. To ensure that security interests are fully considered, regional ocean planning leads will include defense representatives and officials responsible for maintaining the security of our vessels, ports and Nation.
fields.name: security

fields.description: The Mid-Atlantic region is well known for nutrient-rich and highly productive waters. Its estuaries, salt marshes, sea grasses, barrier islands, cold water corals, and submarine canyons provide spawning, nursery, and forage habitats that support diverse resident and migratory marine life including invertebrates, seabirds, fishes, and marine mammals.
fields.overview:
The Mid-Atlantic is well known for nutrient-rich and highly productive waters. The region is a transitional area between the rocky shores of New England and the gently sloping South Atlantic, and it is influenced by two large estuaries, Chesapeake Bay and Delaware Bay. As a result, the Mid-Atlantic region is home to a wealth of complex ecosystems and its estuaries, salt marshes, sea grasses, barrier islands, cold water corals, and submarine canyons provide spawning, nursery, and forage habitats that support diverse resident and migratory marine life including invertebrates, seabirds, fishes, and marine mammals.

The topography is mostly flat, but features sandy shoals and swales, sand wedges and waves, and a broad continental shelf embedded cold water coral patch habitats and incised by submarine canyons along the shelf-slope break. These areas support biologically diverse and abundant benthic (seafloor) macrofauna, demersal fish, and foraging concentrations of sea birds, sea ducks, and bottlenose dolphins. Benthic habitats contain over 2000 species of invertebrates such as marine worms, sponges, shrimp, crab, clams, scallops, snails, sea stars, and anemones. Another invertebrate--corals--establish reefs that are known to be habitat for black seabass and tautog though research on the locations and extents of these ecologically important patchy habitats is scant.

Demersal fish (or groundfish) are characterized by their close association with the seafloor for feeding, spawning, and juvenile nursery areas. The Mid-Atlantic region is particularly productive for demersal fish with some such as summer flounder and black seabass supporting major historic and current recreational and commercial fisheries.

Diadromous fish use both freshwater and marine habitats during their life cycle and these species have great cultural and ecological significance in the Mid-Atlantic region. The diadromous fish of the region—striped bass, alewife, American eel, American Shad, Atlantic salmon, Atlantic sturgeon, Atlantic tomcod, blueback herring, hickory shad, rainbow smelt, sea-run brook trout, and shortnose sturgeon--provide an important energy link between freshwater, estuarine, and marine food webs and many of these species are found only in the Northwest Atlantic ocean.

Large pelagic fish are migratory are typically found well above the seafloor in the water column. Pelagic species play a key ecological role as predators that regulate their prey communities and structure marine food webs. Some inhabit the region only seasonally and many of the details of their life history are not known. A selection of important species includes albacore tuna, Atlantic bluefin tuna, blue marlin, swordfish, great hammerhead shark, sand tiger shark, sandbar shark. The wide ranging distribution of these species across diverse habitat types, their roles as apex predators, and their threatened population status make them ripe for inclusion in regional spatial and conservation plans.

Marine mammals are large migratory species that use this region primarily in spring and summer when food is abundant. Due to their seasonal abundance and charismatic nature, marine mammals have a long-standing, complex relationship with humans in this region. Ten species, among them bottlenose dolphin, fin whale, harbor porpoise, humpback whale, North Atlantic right whale, and sperm whale are important cultural and biodiversity icons of the region.

Sea turtles use both oceanic (inner shelf region and offshore) and terrestrial (beach) ecosystems. Their highly migratory and long life history characteristics present unique challenges to their continued protection and recovery. Sea turtles may have once comprised an important component of the region’s coastal food webs, consuming prey including fish, invertebrates, and sea grasses. Three species of sea turtle (green, leatherback and loggerhead) are present in the Mid-Atlantic.

The varied habitats and abundant resources of the Mid-Atlantic support a highly diverse group of coastal and marine birds that depend on both the oceanic and terrestrial ecosystems of the region throughout the year. Millions of birds pass through the region, which is located along the globally significant migration corridor of the Atlantic Flyway, while traveling between breeding and wintering grounds that span the entire Western Hemisphere. Species of high conservation concern, like the Red Knot and Whimbrel depend on high quality coastal habitats for critical stopover areas. Pelagic species, like the Northern Gannet and Audubon’s Shearwater, use open water habitats during both migration and wintering seasons. Shorebirds, waterbirds and waterfowl, such as the Piping Plover, American Oystercatcher, Least Terns, Black Duck and Brant breed or feed along shorelines in the region and can be heavily impacted by increasing human pressure to these coastal systems. Many of the species occurring in the Mid-Atlantic rank as species of high conservation concern.

Tidal flows, complex seasonal temperature and circulation patterns, and varied seafloor topography combine to create both persistent and shifting habitats that serve as critical resources tracked by Mid-Atlantic marine species, and give rise to upwellings that fuel plankton blooms and key forage species such as menhaden, squid and butterfish. Millions of seabirds, invertebrates, fishes, marine mammals, and large pelagic fishes such as tunas and marlins use diverse Mid-Atlantic habitat and forage resources in specific ways. Cross shelf (east-west) migrants like summer flounder and black seabass and north-south migrants like striped bass, menhaden, and large whales all traverse the region twice a year as they move from southern and near shore locations in winter to offshore or northern locations in summer.

The MARCO Ocean Data Portal has compiled habitat data, as well as known distributions and abundances of many of the key fish, mammal, bird, and reptile species found in the Mid-Atlantic region. In the future, additional data will be added to round out the collection and to allow regional planners to make management and policy decisions that are compatible with and enhance the conservation of these animals and their ecosystem.
fields.name: conservation

fields.description: Offshore wind in the Mid-Atlantic holds more than 60,000 Megawatts of potential energy — that’s 10% of total U.S. offshore potential. This huge resource could help meet the growing electricity demand in the region, while reducing carbon emissions.
fields.overview:
Offshore wind has the potential to be a key domestic renewable energy source, especially for the major cities and large population centers along the East coast of the U.S. The Mid-Atlantic’s offshore wind resources have the potential to produce close to 200 gigawatts of energy every year, enough to power 40 million U.S. homes. Someday, the region’s ocean wave energy could generate an additional 50,000 gigawatts of power and contribute even more significantly to the U.S. energy supply. These renewable energy sources could help meet growing electricity demands in the region and help to reduce carbon emissions.

Production of electricity from renewable sources, such as wind and ocean waves, may be less damaging to the environment than production through burning of fossil fuels, like oil, natural gas, and coal because renewable energy facilities produce much lower emissions of greenhouse gasses and other harmful pollutants such as arsenic, lead and mercury. Additionally, renewable energy production may be more cost effective and efficient than traditional methods because once infrastructure is built, the amount of energy produced is quite stable for the remainder of that system’s lifespan. While the inputs (wind and waves) may fluctuate daily or seasonally they should remain consistent over longer time scales, allowing producers and consumers to rely on steady energy levels.

The Department of the Interior has identified Wind Planning Areas (WPA)--locations that may be suitable for wind development--along the Atlantic Ocean’s outer shelf. Data are being collected inside and outside these high priority areas so regulators and stakeholders can make informed and responsible judgments when issuing permits and making siting and investment decisions. Annual average wind speeds are an indication of the potential available energy at a location. Here, wind speeds modeled from limited observations by the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) and AWS Truepower are expressed at a height of 90 meters above the ocean surface where wind turbine hubs are likely to be located.

Not all the wind and waves that exist offshore are available for harvest however, and all potential energy estimates should be constrained to account for various environmental and socioeconomic factors that may exist in an area. Some of these constraints include potential overlapping use conflicts with shipping lanes, marine mammal, bird, and bat migration pathways, and traditional areas for fishing and recreational use. Infrastructure may need to be built far enough from shore to address concerns over impacts to scenic views, but close enough that the cost of bringing the electricity to shore is not prohibitive. All of these issues should be accounted for in regional ocean planning and the MARCO Ocean Data Portal provides key information that will help to raise awareness of the potential for renewable energy and support decision maker’s efforts to manage resources effectively and minimize conflicts.
fields.name: energy

fields.description: The Mid-Atlantic ports are some of the busiest in the nation’s seaport network, which unloads $3.8 billion in goods each day.
fields.overview:
Mid-Atlantic maritime industries include shipping, transport, tourism, dredging, offshore sand mining, and some of the nation’s busiest ports at New York-New Jersey, Philadelphia, Wilmington, Baltimore, and Norfolk. These ports are crucial links in the nation’s transportation system, constitute a key element of the economy, employ many thousands of people, and have the potential to serve as environmental stewards of our region’s harbors and surrounds.

The U.S. seaport network unloads $3.8 billion in goods each day and Mid-Atlantic ports are a huge contributor, maintaining several national distinctions. The country’s top port for fruits and juices is Wilmington; the fourth busiest tanker port is Philadelphia; products that go through Baltimore’s ports reach over a third of the country within a day and anything entering the U.S. on wheels--from cars to giant tractors--alight in Baltimore, making it the nation’s top Ro-Ro (roll on-roll off) port. The world’s largest natural deep water harbor is at Hampton Roads and it stays ice-free throughout the year, making it suitable for a conglomeration of military facilities, coal piers, shipyards, and miles of waterfront property and beaches which add to the diversity and stability of our nation. The region supports important points of departure for the nation’s cruise ship industry and, in 2011, close to one million people vacationed on ocean cruises originating in New York and Baltimore.

The MARCO Ocean Data Portal contains Automatic Identification System (AIS) information from 2009, processed to focus on highly travelled shipping routes near port entrances. AIS data are collected by the U.S. Coast Guard using automated two-way radio transmissions that track real-time vessel information such as ship identity, purpose, course, and speed, primarily in coastal waters. AIS is required on all passenger vessels and vessels with gross tonnage greater than 300, so smaller vessel traffic is not represented in the database. MARCO is currently consulting with the Coast Guard and shipping industry stakeholders to evaluate how well these data indicate total ship traffic density and what additional data may be needed to fully represent shipping activity.

The viability, safety, and growth needs of the commercial shipping industry need to be addressed in regional ocean planning. Accordingly, MARCO will consult with major port and navigation stakeholders to evaluate what additional map data may be needed to inform regional ocean planning decisions and help ensure stakeholder interests are well represented.
fields.name: maritime-industries

fields.description: Numerous federal, regional, and state political and management boundaries of the Mid-Atlantic are compiled here to provide a regulatory context to help facilitate well-informed ocean planning decisions.
fields.overview:
Numerous management boundaries in the Mid-Atlantic are compiled here to provide administrative and regulatory contexts to help facilitate well-informed ocean planning decisions.

Boundaries are provided courtesy of the responsible agencies and these parties should be consulted to ensure that map layers represented here are current and correctly interpreted. The boundaries presented here should not be considered to be legally binding.
fields.name: administrative
Especies en Lista Roja o Cites
Especies de Deistribucion Restringida a Columbia
Deepwater Coral Habitat Areas of Particular Concern
Áreas de Zonificación y Manejo de Manglares
Zonificacion Area Marina Protegida de los Archipielagos del Rosario y San Bernardo

fields.description: The revenue sharing boundary provides for eligible states to claim a percentage of the share of oil, gas, or wind energy revenues when a federal lease is within three miles of the Submerged Lands Act (SLA) boundary.
fields.data_overview: The revenue sharing boundary was established under Section 8(g) of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act.  It provides for eligible states to claim a percentage of the share of oil, gas, or wind energy revenues when a federal lease is within three miles of the Submerged Lands Act (SLA) boundary.
fields.data_source: Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Mapping and Boundary Branch
fields.data_notes: Because GIS projection and topology functions can change or generalize coordinates, these GIS files are considered to be approximate and are not an official record for the exact Submerged Lands Act Boundary.
fields.name: Limit of OCSLA '8(g)' zone

fields.data_overview: Known areas of explosive weapons (e.g., bombs, mines, and shells) that did not explode when they were employed and may still pose a risk of detonation years after being used or discarded.
fields.name: Unexploded Ordnances

fields.description: Known shipwrecks. These areas may be used in recreational pursuits for scuba diving, fishing, archaeology, historical study, and recovery of materials.
fields.data_overview: Density map of reported shipwrecks illustrating the prevalence of potential historic period archaeological sites on the Atlantic OCS. Because this information was compiled using sources that have unreliable location information, this data does not represent a complete record of potential archaeological sites within a particular geographic area and is not intended for decision-making or planning purposes.
fields.name: Shipwreck Density

fields.description: Each coastal State may claim a territorial sea that extends seaward up to 12 nautical miles from its baselines.
fields.data_overview: Each coastal State may claim a territorial sea that extends seaward up to 12 nautical miles from its baselines. The coastal State exercises sovereignty over its territorial sea, the air space above it, and the seabed and subsoil beneath it.
fields.data_notes: These limits and boundaries do not represent the official depiction. For official depiction, please see NOAA's paper or raster nautical charts.
fields.name: 12NM Territorial Sea

fields.description: Each coastal State may claim a contiguous zone adjacent to and beyond its territorial sea that extends seaward up to 24 nautical miles from its baselines.
fields.data_overview: Each coastal State may claim a contiguous zone adjacent to and beyond its territorial sea that extends seaward up to 24 nautical miles from its baselines. In its contiguous zone, a coastal State may exercise the control necessary to prevent the infringement of its customs, fiscal, immigration or sanitary laws and regulations within its territory or territorial sea, and punish infringement of those laws and regulations committed within its territory or territorial sea.
fields.data_notes: These limits and boundaries do not represent the official depiction. For official depiction, please see NOAA's paper or raster nautical charts.
fields.name: 24NM Territorial Sea

fields.description: The SLA boundary defines the seaward limit of a state's submerged lands and the landward boundary of federally managed OCS lands.  In the BOEM Atlantic Region it is projected 3 nautical miles offshore from the baseline.
fields.data_overview: The Submerged Lands Act (SLA) boundary line (also known as State Seaward Boundary or Fed State Boundary) defines the seaward limit of a state's submerged lands and the landward boundary of federally managed OCS lands. In the BOEM Atlantic Region it is projected 3 nautical miles offshore from the baseline.
fields.data_source: Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Mapping and Boundary Branch
fields.data_notes: Because GIS projection and topology functions can change or generalize coordinates, these GIS files are considered to be approximate and are not an official record for the exact Submerged Lands Act Boundary.
fields.name: Submerged Lands Act Boundary

fields.description: Boundaries of Regional Councils on the Ocean that exist in the Atlantic Ocean.
fields.data_overview: Boundaries of Regional Councils on the Ocean that exist in the Atlantic Ocean.
fields.data_source: NOAA Coastal Services Center via MarineCadastre.gov
fields.data_notes: Unofficial boundary for Regional Ocean Councils which are state and federal partnerships with the goal of engaging in regional protection and balanced use of ocean and coastal resources.
fields.name: Regional Ocean Partnerships

fields.data_overview:
Federally - and internationally - recognized political, legal, and resource management boundaries. 

Submerged Lands Act Boundary – also known as the state seaward boundary, this line serves to distinguish state and federal jurisdictions (3 nautical miles seaward from mean low low water [MLLW]).

8g Revenue Sharing Line (Limit of OCSLA '8(g)' zone) – area where revenues from energy resources are shared by federal and coastal state governments (extends seaward 3 nautical miles from Submerged Lands Act Boundary).

Territorial Sea Boundary (12NM Territorial Sea) – region of U.S. sovereignty (extends from MLLW to 12 nautical miles from shore).

Contiguous Zone Boundary (24NM Territorial Sea) – area of limited control in preventing or punishing infringement of customs or laws (extends from MLLW to 24 nautical miles from shore; alternately extends seaward 12 nautical miles from Territorial Sea Boundary).

Exclusive Economic Zone (200NM EEZ and Maritime Boundaries) – area of sole rights for resource use, research, and protection (extends from Territorial Sea Boundary to 200 nautical miles from shore).
fields.name: Marine Jurisdictions

fields.description: Areas with naval or military presence. Caution should be used if navigating near these areas.
fields.data_overview: Areas with naval or military presence. Caution should be used if navigating near these areas.
fields.data_notes: This layer is being consumed directly as a web mapping service from MarineCadastre.gov.
fields.name: Danger Zones & Restricted Areas

fields.description: Annual average wind speeds are closely related to the available energy at a particular location. In these data, wind speeds are categorized by their value at a height of 90 meters above the surface. The data were created by the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) and AWS Truepower.
fields.data_overview: Annual average wind speeds are closely related to the available energy at a particular location. In these data, wind speeds are categorized by their value at a height of 90 meters above the surface. The data were created by the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) and AWS Truepower. Wind speed data for all of the MARCO states was created as part of onshore wind mapping projects. Speed data was extrapolated to 50 nautical miles offshore by NREL. The 90 m wind speed was calculated by a linear interpolation between 70 m and 100 m wind speeds. A horizontal discontinuity (seam) in the wind resource is present at the border of New York and New Jersey. Discontinuities in the data result from offshore data that is based on different versions of the numerical model used for the different onshore mapping projects and the way the extrapolation software interprets the data on either side of the seam.
fields.data_notes: This layer represents an estimate of offshore annual average wind speeds and is based primarily on data extrapolated from onshore wind data, which is a source of uncertainty in the dataset. For more information visit nrel.gov and search for Technical Report TP-500-45889.
fields.name: Wind Speed

fields.legend_subtitle: Total Commodity Tonnage by millions of tons
fields.data_overview: Principal Ports are politically defined by port limits or US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) projects. These data exclude non-USACE projects that are not authorized for publication. The determination for the published Principal Ports is based upon the total tonnage for the port for the particular year; therefore the top 150 list can vary from year to year. The Principal Port file contains USACE port codes, names, and commodity tonnage summaries (total tons, domestic, foreign, imports and exports). Original source file compiled in 2010, verified in 2012.
fields.name: Principal Ports

fields.description: Each coastal State may claim an Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) beyond and adjacent to its territorial sea that extends seaward up to 200 nautical miles from its baselines (or out to a maritime boundary with another coastal State).
fields.data_overview: Each coastal State may claim an Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) beyond and adjacent to its territorial sea that extends seaward up to 200 nautical miles from its baselines (or out to a maritime boundary with another coastal State).
fields.data_notes: These limits and boundaries do not represent the official depiction. For official depiction, please see NOAA's paper or raster nautical charts.
fields.name: 200NM EEZ and Maritime Boundaries

fields.description: This data layer shows both the coastal vulnerability index (CVI) and the data from which the CVI is calculated (tides, wave height, relative sea-level rise, coastal slope, geomorphology, and shoreline erosion and accretion rate) for the U.S. Atlantic Coast.
fields.data_overview:
The goal of this project is to provide a preliminary overview of the relative susceptibility of the Nation's coast to sea-level rise through the use of a coastal vulnerability index (CVI). This initial classification is based upon the variables geomorphology, regional coastal slope, tide range, wave height, relative sea-level rise and shoreline erosion and accretion rates. The combination of these variables and their association to each other furnish a broad overview of regions where physical changes are likely to occur due to sea-level rise.

The purpose of this data layer is to allow the user to view both the coastal vulnerability index (CVI) and the data from which the CVI is calculated (tides, wave height, relative sea-level rise, coastal slope, geomorphology, and shoreline erosion and accretion rate) for the U.S. Atlantic Coast. The CVI provides insight into the relative potential for coastal change due to future sea-level rise.
fields.data_notes: These data were created to be used for planning purposes only. They are designed to give a broad overview of vulnerability to sea level rise at a National scale.
fields.name: Sea Level Rise Vulnerability
High Seas Areas Closed Bottom Fishing
